For Release Weekend Editions, Dec. 22-24, and Thereafter
Christmas Spirit Tested In Disaster-Stricken Spots
With BC-Hugo-Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Outwardly, it's been Christmas as usual: shops filled, trees flocked, lights strung. But for many people in places scarred by disaster, this has not been an ordinary holiday season. This Christmas will be more deeply felt and longer remembered by those who were touched by the northern California earthquake, the Alaska oil spill and the tornado that killed nine schoolchildren near Newburgh, N.Y. _In San Francisco, the Rev. Cecil Williams of Glide Memorial Methodist Church said this holiday season presents special challenges to those who suffered losses in the October earthquake. ``No one should be homeless on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day,'' he said. ``And we've decided anyone who needs a place, we're going to put them up.'' Glide has been raising money to pay for rooms at local residential hotels to house up to 1,000 people. The church also planned to hand out more than 9,500 bags of groceries and 5,000 toys, and feed more than 6,000 people on both Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. Some Bay Area charities complained that the surge of giving after the quake has subsided, even while the need remains strong. At the Volunteer Bureau of Santa Cruz County, spokeswoman Maria Norena said collections have been meager for new clothing and toys. And, she said, ``This year we need it more than ever.'' _In Alaska's port city of Valdez, site of the nation's worst oil spill last March, a dreary, rainy summer has given way to a dreary, slushy winter. The community's population ballooned to about 13,000 people from its normal 3,000 during the summer's cleanup frenzy. This winter, the number has shrunk to about 4,000. ``I think there's kind of a letdown after a busy summer,'' said City Manager Doug Griffin. ``I don't think that is necessarily bad. I think after all the activity, people need to catch their breath.'' City Councilman Dennis Holtz, who owns the Food Mart, said his sales have been strong. ``But I'm sensing the community is not upbeat,'' he added. ``I think people are tired from the long summer, and the spirit, the Christmas spirit, is not present. I just think everybody's beat.'' _In Newburgh, the Rev. Ted Bechtel of First Reformed Church said people are beginning to put the tragedy at East Coldenham Elementary school behind them, ``although we all realize it's going to be with us a long time.'' ``For a lot of the families involved and others in the community, it's going to take a lot of the edge and joy off of Christmastime,'' Bechtel said. ``But kids get caught up in the season and the time of year and are generally doing well.'' One of those killed, 8-year-old Peter Orsino, had attended Sunday school at Bechtel's church. Peter's family is ``handling it pretty well,'' Bechtel said. ``They have other children and they're trying to celebrate a normal Christmas. But I know another family, they don't want to decorate, they don't want to celebrate Christmas at all.''
